video.title: Laravel PHP Framework Tutorial - Full Course for Beginners (2019)
video.description:
Learn Laravel 5.8 by creating an Instagram clone in this full tutorial course for beginners. Laravel is a free, open-source PHP web framework used for creating web applications. 

💻Code: https://github.com/coderstape/freecodegram

⭐️Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00) Introduction
⌨️ (1:14) What is Laravel?
⌨️ (2:07) Installing Laravel
⌨️ (5:30) First look at the project
⌨️ (7:15) Intro to php artisan
⌨️ (11:42) Generating login flow with make:auth
⌨️ (12:04) Setting Up the Front End with Node and NPM
⌨️ (20:00) Migrations and Setting Up SQLite
⌨️ (26:00) Designing the UI from Instagram
⌨️ (42:12) Adding Username to the Registration Flow
⌨️ (58:35) Creating the Profiles Controller
⌨️ (1:04:00) RESTful Resource Controller
⌨️ (1:09:10) Passing Data to the View
⌨️ (1:10:20) Adding the Profiles Mode, Migration and Table
⌨️ (1:17:30) Adding Eloquent Relationships
⌨️ (1:28:10) Fetching the Record From The Database
⌨️ (1:30:00) Adding Posts to the Database & Many To Many Relationship
⌨️ (2:04:24) Creating Through a Relationship
⌨️ (2:08:12) Uploading/Saving the Image to the Project
⌨️ (2:19:19) Resizing Images with Intervention Image PHP Library
⌨️ (2:27:42) Route Model Binding
⌨️ (2:31:48) Editing the Profile
⌨️ (2:46:46) Restricting/Authorizing Actions with a Model Policy
⌨️ (2:54:50) Editing the Profile Image
⌨️ (3:00:00) Automatically Creating A Profile Using Model Events
⌨️ (3:12:56) Default Profile Image
⌨️ (3:19:48) Follow/Unfollow Profiles Using a Vue.js Component
⌨️ (3:31:28) Many To Many Relationship
⌨️ (3:46:33) Calculating Followers Count and Following Count
⌨️ (3:48:55) Laravel Telescope
⌨️ (3:51:44) Showing Posts from Profiles The User Is Following
⌨️ (4:01:03) Pagination with Eloquent
⌨️ (4:03:25) N + 1 Problem & Solution
⌨️ (4:05:21) Make Use of Cache for Expensive Query
⌨️ (4:11:44) Sending Emails to New Registered Users
⌨️ (4:21:51) Wrapping Up
⌨️ (4:22:37) Closing Remarks & What's Next In your Learning

🎥Course from Coder's Tape. Check out their YouTube channel for more great Laravel tutorials: https://www.youtube.com/coderstape

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

replies.author: Denis Khakimov
replies.text:
Чтобы скомпилировать файлы, можно просто ввести в консоли что-то вроде: _npx vite build._

А чтобы включить режим отслеживания изменений и автоматической сборки, достаточно добавить опцию _-w_ (или _--watch):_ _npx vite build --watch._

Хотя проще всего добавить следующий код в раздел "scripts" файла "package.json": _"watch": "vite build --watch"_ и запускать его командой _npm run watch._

topLevelComment.author: Lim Elnoll
topLevelComment.text:
For those who couldn't run the command: php artisan make:auth successfully, the newer versions of Laravel have adopted the next commands to be replacing the previous one: 
1) Run the command: composer require laravel/ui
2) The run the command: php artisan ui vue --auth
And voila, the authentication scaffolding generated successfully! 

Best regards.

For those who getting error message on laravel 8.0 and later. 
After running command
php artisan make:auth its deprecated now.


Now you have to use.
1. composer require laravel/breeze --dev
2. php artisan breeze:install
3. npm install
4. npm run dev
5. php artisan migrate

topLevelComment.author: Fiachra Horan
topLevelComment.text: When you're making your ProfilePolicy.php you don't use a strict comparison, this is because the id in the user table is an id in the migration and considered an int. But the user_id in the profile table is an unsignedBigInteger in the migration and is considered a string when you var_dump. The same happens if you were to use foreignId in your migration. So is there a better way we can type match these?  Ref 2:49:30

topLevelComment.author: pant13
topLevelComment.text:
query to extract the posts of the profiles  that a specific user(the authenticated one) follows:

select posts.caption,posts.image
from users inner join posts
on (users.id=posts.user_id)
where users.id in
(
     select users.id
     from users inner join profiles on (users.id=profiles.id)
     where profiles.id in
     (
            select profiles.id
            from users inner join profile_user on (users.id=profile_user.user_id)
            inner join profiles on (profile_user.profile_id=profiles.id)
            where (users.id = $auth()->user()->id )
     )

)
order by posts.id desc

amazing how this is done in only 2 rows in laravel...

topLevelComment.author: pant13
topLevelComment.text:
i ignored laravel for some time but it really spares you so much time. For example, with raw php, you would have to open a session whenever a user logged in, get the session in miltiple .php pages and manually add it(except if you used an sql trigger) as the foreign key to the profile table, whenever the authenticated user created a post. Not to mention that you would have to manually check if the authenticated user pressed to create the post while being in their profile(for example,if the user with id=4 is logged in and they are at the profile of the user with id=10, they wouldn't have permission to add new post there). Laravel does it all in one line
Or for example if you wanted to display the username and the info of the profile of the user with,say,id=7, you would have to join the two tables and add the id of 7(which you would grab with a Get request) in the where clause in order to display the material

topLevelComment.author: Donbros
topLevelComment.text:
If one have problems with 

"FIX (22:00) - If you try to use "vim" over Windows cmd: for Windows users, "vim" should not works. So, being at the project folder, try: copy con database\database.sqlite (press enter, so F6 then, enter again). It will create the file with nothing inside. METHOD 2: re-create this file using a different method, like (under windows os) right-click on the project folder, "create new text file" (but rename the extension txt to sqlite!) and rename it to database.sqlite"

You have to delete all emptys spaces and rubbish within database.sqlite file and "php artisan migrate" command will work without issues

topLevelComment.author: Ashraful Islam
topLevelComment.text:
TRICK 1: ------------------------
If anyone face sqlite Database error, you can follow this approach: 
In config/database.php file:

'sqlite' => [
              'driver' => 'sqlite',
              'database' => dirname(__DIR__).'/database/database.sqlite',
            ],
Then run following command:

php artisan config:cache
php artisan config:clear

TRICK 2:-------------------------
To compile scss file automatically when there's a new save, run this. 
npm run watch

topLevelComment.author: Kiran Anand
topLevelComment.text:
Laravel 8 - Pagination - 4:02:55 - Massive Button Issue

If using Bootstrap / not TailWind... add the following line of code to the boot(){} function in app\providers\AppServiceProvider.php:

Paginator::useBootstrap();

Massive buttons now gone.

Installing Bootstrap

Head over to your terminal, navigate to your Laravel 7  project and run the following command:

After successfully installing the package, we install Bootstrap 4 in our application using the following command:
$ php artisan ui bootstrap
$ npm install && npm run dev

topLevelComment.author: Ahmad Sarwar
topLevelComment.text:
(This is a copy paste to bring more awareness to these issues)
### FIX ISSUES ###
FIX/TIP (4:15) - echo $PATH does not work under windows (prompt). Instead, you must try just "path" (remove the quotations) on cmd/prompt.

FIX (9:38) - ERROR "Could not open input file: artisan" when run "php artisan serve": As he said, we must run this command inside the project folder. 

FIX (11:45) - make:auth works only on Laravel 5.8 and older versions.* The newer version, try: 
1. composer require laravel/ui
2. php artisan ui vue --auth
3. npm install && npm run dev

FIX (22:00) - If you try to use "vim" over Windows cmd: for Windows users, "vim" should not works. So, being at the project folder, try: copy con database\database.sqlite (press enter, so F6 then, enter again). It will create the file with nothing inside. METHOD 2: re-create this file using a different method, like (under windows os) right-click on the project folder, "create new text file" (but rename the extension txt to sqlite!) and rename it to database.sqlite

FIX (23:35) - console echoes for php artisan migrate: "Could not find driver (SQL: PRAGMA...": Just open php.ini and uncomment extension=pdo_sqlite (or extension=pdo_mysql if you use it).
If this error persists, even after uncommenting  extension=pdo_sqlite, with PHP Warning "PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library 'pdo_sqlite'". Try fix that by typing: 
sudo apt-get install php7.4-sqlite
(Thanks to @Sjors Peterse)

1:08:00 In version 8 of Laravel the User.php  has been moved to 'Models' folder, so you have to write it like this: use App\Models\User;

replies.author: Pascal Segoete
replies.text:
@Ahmed Mamdouh FOLLOW THESE STEPS 


1 Install composer
  -Open CMD
  -type composer and press enter 
2.H:\> composer global require "laravel/installer"
3.H:\> laravel new laravelApp
  check on your project location where project laravelApp" is created 

4 composer require laravel/ui --dev - for UI Auth 
                      // Generate login / registration scaffolding...
   -For VueJs preset --> php artisan ui vue --auth  (VueJs is a javascript framework) 
                         php artisan ui bootstrap--auth   (Bootstrap is a HTML&CSS framework)
5. npm Install & npm run dev

topLevelComment.author: gargameo
topLevelComment.text:
If you are struggling with installing Laravel with oh my ZSH on Linux, try this:
run ` composer global about`
you will see something like: "Changed current directory to /home/username/.config/composer".
That means that your vendor dir is located in that path. 
Now you have two options. You don't have to do both of them it's either/or
1. add composer to your path (in .zshrc file) which is in home dir (hidden), show it with ctrl+H: 
just add this line anywhere in this file
`export PATH="$HOME/.config/composer/vendor/bin:$PATH"` 
2.  add an alias in .zshrc file:
`alias laravel="$HOME/.config/composer/vendor/bin/laravel".`
Now you are pointing to the 'laravel' file in your filesys using the same command as you would normally.

topLevelComment.author: Samay bhattacharyya
topLevelComment.text:
If you get an error at 21:00 (while creating database.sqlite), that probably means you do not have vim editor installed. A quick way around that would work for any WINDOWS user is copy and paste this: 
notepad database/database.sqlite
This will open notepad and will ask you to create that file. Hit create and close the notepad. That would do the work.
Enjoy Laravel!

topLevelComment.author: Diego Sayron
topLevelComment.text:
*### FIX ISSUES ###*
*FIX/TIP (**4:15**) - echo $PATH* does not work under windows (prompt). Instead, you must try just "path" (remove the quotations) on cmd/prompt.

*FIX (**9:38**)* - ERROR "Could not open input file: artisan" when run "php artisan serve": As he said, we must run this command *inside* the project folder. 

*FIX (**11:45**)* - make:auth works only on Laravel 5.8 and older versions.* The newer version, try: 
1. composer require laravel/ui
2. php artisan ui vue --auth
3. npm install && npm run dev

*FIX (**22:00**) - If you try to use "vim" over Windows cmd:* for Windows users, "vim" should not works. So, being at the project folder, try: copy con database\database.sqlite (press enter, so F6 then, enter again). It will create the file with nothing inside. METHOD 2: re-create this file using a different method, like (under windows os) right-click on the project folder, "create new text file" (but rename the extension txt to sqlite!) and rename it to database.sqlite

*FIX (**23:35**) -* console echoes for php artisan migrate: *"Could not find driver (SQL: PRAGMA...":* Just open php.ini and uncomment extension=pdo_sqlite (or extension=pdo_mysql if you use it).
If this error persists, even after uncommenting  extension=pdo_sqlite, with PHP Warning "PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library 'pdo_sqlite'". Try fix that by typing: 
sudo apt-get install php7.4-sqlite
(Thanks to @Sjors Peterse)

replies.author: Diego Sayron
replies.text: ​@Muhtasim Mahmud Khan Antor Open the start menu, type cmd (hit enter) go to the project folder using "cd" command (i.e: cd c:\myproject), type: copy con database\database.sqlite (press enter, so F6 then, enter again). It will create a file with nothing inside. METHOD 2: re-create this file using a different method, like (under windows os) right-click on the project folder, "create new text file" (rename the extension txt to sqlite!) and rename it to database.sqlite - Tell us if this works for you, okay?

replies.author: Riccardo Manzan
replies.text:
After installing Composer, node, npm (and php), you install everything else in the same way (like require laravel etc.)
Project folders are scaffolded by the laravel installer when you use command 'laravel new <projectname>'.
You install laravel installer using command "composer global require laravel/installer".

Don't forget to use "npm i" and "composer require" after scaffolding project. Those commands will download the dependencies.

To use that commands (npm, composer, php...) you can use powershell or cmd as you like. Personally i use Powershell.
I also use visual studio code with some extensions instead of using phpstorm.

Victor
Great lesson. I’m a noob going inch by inch following your lead to make my project. Thank you. Also subscribed to this and CT.
But I have a question (actually 100’s, but one for now): 
You created the sqlite db (~21:50) using command vim which you said was “…compatible with Windows”. What is that? I tried it and got error. Googled it and only found refs to an IDE/editor VIM. Is it related to that? Another package I have to download (ugh)? Am I right that after all these years Laravel doesn’t include a way to create a database (per many googles searches)?
So I created my db (mysql) in phpMyAdmin, but could not get phpstorm to recognize it. I had changed db_name in .env from Laravel to my own db name, didn’t work. Had some other difficulty with my xampp (reinstall), but not sure if that’s even connected. Could you explain relationship of xampp (running) & artisan serve & artisan up commands? I’m not sure which of those make the connection to the database, but it finally worked all of a sudden and I don’t know why.
Thanks much.
Nate

replies.author: PsY
replies.text: @Nathan Granger i am not sure about phpstorm, maybe it has a built in mysql-client or maybe there's some kind of addon for it, i always use visual studio code as i don't have the monthly money for php storm and it's a veeery nice environment to build up code, actually i think they're quite similar. but phpmyadmin or cpanel (for leased servers/shared hostings) are my tools for creating a new db or commandline/shell of course.

replies.author: Nathan Granger
PsY
replies.text:
​@Nathan Granger 1. He is not using mysql! He is using sqlite which is different and based on a file. he creates this file with vim. The file is an empty text file with an *.sqlite extension i believe. this is the fastest way to set up a dev db environment but i still always use mysql right from the start.

2. if u got mysql and phpmyadmin installed you can create databases via phpmyadmin, this is probably the fastest way. There are also database clients that you could use and connect to your database (e.g. heidisql or mysql workbench). Then there's a way to create databases via command line if mysql is installed. you can create text files and put sql query code in of course (*.sql files) and then import that into the database that's also possible. but phpmyadmin is fastest way, takes only name and then a button click and u got ur database :) then you configure your laravels ".env" file in the root directory and enter the db info there of the empty db u created. next step is in console "php artisan make:migration Migration_Name" inside the laravel root directory. this creates a migration file under "/database/migrations/" that you have to edit. In there you define the table  layouts (mainly the columns you want) and yes, these are php text files as well. There's one migration file per table. check out the docs ;) this course did discuss those steps I believe :) after having set up the migration file you can let laravel write the changes into the database by calling "php artisan migrate" in command line.  Maybe it's best to watch the very beginning of this course again. there's also another in-depth laravel 6 beginner course here on youtube which is as good and clean as this one. it's broken down into several chapters, both courses also follow all design principles you should be using urself ;) good luck!

replies.author: Nathan Granger
replies.text: @PsY Thanks, but I can't create a mysql db from the editor, right? That's what I was trying to do. I found (and presumed) I had to create it in phpmyadmin. I'm just surprised Laravel and/or Phpstorm haven't automated that like they (thankfully) do everything else.

replies.author: PsY

replies.author: Graham Widgery
replies.text:
So I've done some more research here. I believe I edited the posts migration table after doing the migration, and so the table was incomplete or had incorrect column titles.


I did these two commands to go back a step of the migration and then re-run it with my up-to-date migration file:

php artisan migrate:rollback
php artisan migrate


Now the /p/create page works without an error

topLevelComment.author: Denislav Karagiozov
topLevelComment.text:
Also, tip for anyone who wants to use MYSQL over sqlite as given in this tutorial, you have to install and run xampp and click start on APACHE and MySQL, if their names turn green then you go to ADMIN of MYSQL which will send you to a local phpMyAdmin panel. There you click +New on the left to create a new database, you pick a name and then you create it. After thats done, in the .env file you comment out HOST PORT and DATABASE, only leave db connection as mysql username as root and pass is empty (by default, you can set up different users if you so desire) and after that open up database.php in app/config which is a settings file and in there you do the same thing, you change the name of the database in the mysql array to the one you created and you add root as username password is empty. 

You dont need to create a database file using VIM as given here since you need the mysql engine to work and provide drivers for the migrations to work.

topLevelComment.author: NaCℓ
topLevelComment.text:
3:16:34 *PRO TIP* You can use the ?: to accomplish the same goal:
return $this->image ?: 'noimage.jpg';

replies.author: NaCℓ
Ravindra
replies.text:
?: is a Ternary operator,  which works if you provide an image ( 'noimage.jpg'). 
But in normal case if the User chooses to accept default 'No File Chosen'  option and proceeds to 
save the file then code will break. 
?? is a Null coalescing operator which takes care of it if the value is NULL.

topLevelComment.author: Giga
topLevelComment.text:
If anyone is getting PDOException when running `php artisan migrate`, this is how I fixed it (System: Manjaro):


1. pacman -S php-sqlite
2. sudo vim /etc/php/php.ini (sudo because the file is usually read-only, for me this is where it was located, if this isn't the case for you then you can run `sudo find / -name php.ini` to find its location)
3. search for line with pdo_sqlite and uncomment it


`php artisan migrate` should work normally now

topLevelComment.author: Joel Powell
topLevelComment.text:
Amazing tutorial - great work. Another Laravel 6 difference - I was getting empty app.css and wasn't getting any styling on the login screen. I found that you can run:
*composer require laravel/ui*
then
*php artisan ui vue*
then 
*npm install && npm run dev*
Refresh your browser and you are all set. This appears to be the result of refactoring/abstracting how UI (Vue, React, etc.) is used - Vue was baked in as default in Laravel 5.

topLevelComment.author: Isaac Muniz
topLevelComment.text:
First I had to install Composer, and for this I needed to install PHP and add it to my path. Then I needed to install Node.js. Then Laravel through Composer. Composer was automatically added to my path somehow.
It was a long journey just to understand how to do this and get it done. 
Then, the IDE. The one used in the video is PHPStorm which  is not free. And I don't wanna use a free version of something I wont buy.  So I researched a little and I went not with an IDE, but with NOTEPAD++. Then I had to figure out how to open the project folder in Notepad++, which turns out to be just dropping the folder in there.
At this point, more than 3 hours has passed and I didn't even started making the app yet. But I was still confident to keep going cause I had a job interview two days later and I needed to show something, this app would be one of this somethings.
Problems are not over. When I run " php artisan " it doesn't work, I get an error saying that the file " /vendor/autoload.php " doesn't exist. I lost some hour searching about this, till I resolve to uninstall composer and install again through the command line (previously I had done that through the installer). But I didn't did that because I found the command " composer update --no-scripts " which resolved the problem by re-installing Composer and libraries (at least that is what I think it did). PROBLEM SOLVED! Phew... I almost felt like an orgasm when I resolved this because I though I would not. :)
Soon another problem arrived. 500 Server Error when I visit the page. I read that the problem could be either on the .htaccess or the index.php or on permissions. I read that I can create a new test.php file at the Public folder of Laravel with the content ' echo "Hello Word" ' for example an see if I can read it; if I can, the problem would not be in .htaccess file. And also that for the same purpose I could check if the permissions are 755 for index.php. I also read that it could be external connections being all attempted at the same time, making them time out. And that removing this external connections could solve the "500 server error" problem. I changed a little the .thaccess by commenting out RewriteRule ^ %1 [L,R=301] as I read somewhere and yet it didn't worked.
Following the same problem, I also read that I could fix the 500 Server Error by " increase the values of FastCGI configurations which located in file "/etc/httpd/conf.d/fcgid.conf" " - I don't even have a /etc folder in my project, so I didn't followed that tip.
Turns out that this tutorial didn't help much and I couldn't follow it, after lots of hours of struggle with Laravel. Why does it need to be so complicated? I'll find another tutorial that may guide me better. I need a Laravel app done for tomorrow! I nee that job.

replies.author: ManuAlvarado22
replies.text:
Most likely you have vi, one that is similar to vim.


If you are using a Linux distribution like Debian, Ubuntu or Linux Mint; you can use nano, and to save the file, you hit ctrl + o.


Or you can just create the file with your preferred text editor!

replies.author: Jonneh
replies.text:
Hello Youcef! To start off, vim is a text editor, which you may have to install on your machine; so that is the first thing you must do if you haven't already.

Assuming you have installed vim, your next step is to put the directory containing the vim.exe into your %PATH% environment variable. Once you've added this directory to your %PATH%, you should be able to run vim from the command line without issue.

replies.author: Hardy Jay
replies.text: The difference is: {{Auth::user()->username}} fetch the current logged in user, but when in another user's profile and you need his/her username, {{$user->username}} does it.

topLevelComment.author: Kyle Maxwell
topLevelComment.text: Unfortunately, this suffers from the same BS that most Laravel tutorials suffer from: he simultaneously believes that you're such an amateur that you're hosting your site on your home PC, yet also have access to a dedicated db Server just for your database.  It's horsecrap.  For example, he tells you "localhost" won't work.  In actuality, "localhost" is the ONLY thing that will work.  That is, unless you're Amazon, and don't have your db on the same server as your .php.  Most people do NOT have a setup like this, and so the tutorial fails right out of the gate.

topLevelComment.author: Mike Goodsell
topLevelComment.text: This is perhaps the best tutorial of any kind I have ever seen. I don't know if it's because I was impressed with Laravel's functionality, or the instructor's delivery. Maybe a combo of both. Everything worked, and everything was clear and concise. It was jam-packed with information, and took me 3 days to get through, and will probably take me another month to fully understand, but, as a tutorial, I was able to understand and follow everything being said and my results matched the instructors. Many real world issues were touched on. The only issues I had on my end was the new auth() functionality, which someone else mentioned. Additionally, I was not using PHPStorm, so, in a couple of places use paths were added within the tutorial that were not automatically added in mine - However, since everything else was so concise, I was able to debug without much issue. All in all, an exceptional beginning course. Five stars. Thank you.

topLevelComment.author: Manish Srivastava
topLevelComment.text:
In Laravel 6.0 make:auth no longer exists:php artisan make:auth  ( which works for Laravel 5.8 and older versions )
Solution:
Run :composer require laravel/ui
php artisan ui:auth
You can also generate the views only with:
php artisan ui:auth --views

replies.author: Hilal Lazrak
replies.text:
I had the same issue, and I did search for a solution and figured out how to fix it, you need to install the the required packages:
composer require laravel/ui --dev
// Generate basic scaffolding...
php artisan ui vue
php artisan ui react

// Generate login / registration scaffolding...
php artisan ui vue --auth
php artisan ui react --auth

Remember to re-run :  npm run dev

replies.author: Armin B
replies.text: You could add it to public directory, for example: public/custom.css and then reference it inside of your layouts/app.blade.php file, in the header, just like you do with regular css files. Best way with laravel is to actually use sass and compile the sass code into public/app.css file, but that's a bit more complex and I suggest you use the first approach I mentioned.

replies.author: Job Jongebloet
replies.text:
Make sure you have the right req; 
rm -rf vendor
rm -rf storage/framework/cache/*

rm -rf storage/framework/session/*

rm -rf storage/framework/views/*

rm composer.lock

composer clear-cache

composer install

Copy .env.example to .env:

(cp -a .env.example .env ) or whatever OS you use 

Generate a key:

php artisan key:generate

Clear cache;
php artisan config:cache

start server;
php artisan serve

Don't do this inside the Storm term, RUN CMD AS ADMINISTRATOR

JUST LOOK AT YOUR LOG STORAGE -> LOG
or google your problem

Shouldn't have been too hard to figure out yourself by searching the web. It's not rocket science.
